messages.message:
Hey team, we have a Commercial customer building a Passport solution on AI Hub for a POC. They are running into performance issues around MRZ codes that I haven't been able to resolve for them.
• Using the pre-built classes and Passport App, the MRZ code field has mistakes in the results even for the sample files (sometimes). This is the customer's sample run link (https://aihub.instabase.com/review/549031b5-4f80-4941-98ab-92b6641c3afe) with incorrect extractions.
• I tried to improve the prompt, but the underlying issue seems to be the OCR and layout processing (see 3 examples below). Almost every passport seems to get put in this format which really limits what we can do with prompting to get the info out. 
• As far as I can tell, the only solution here would be include stricter validations. This means significantly lowering the automation rate which means we lose out to their current incumbent solution. 
Do we have any solutions for Passports we could use here based on previous work? Is there anything else we could use to improve performance here? I'm aware that there is a set structure to MRZ codes that I'd provide to the customer to use as a validation if nothing else.

cc @david.lee @Nico @Piyush @Pramod Munemanik @Nithin
@Nithin @Varun K V - were we able to resolve the MRZ issue on our solution as well? I know we discussed this earlier on the <#C053455QN1M|> channel
FYI they are using the IB solution as the basis to get out of the box performance, so it would appear not unless this app is not up to date?
@Rakesh any thoughts on how to improve the digitization output?

It seems like the extraction of characters, numbers, and filler characters in between ('<') seem to be fairly accurate. Most of the problem I'm observing is in the trailing filler characters. The scanned document to OCR extracted values seem to be accurate, but OCR to document reasoning output is where the trailing characters either get cut (e.g. 23 trailing chars in OCR results to 21 in field value), or extra ones get added.

For example here, the first line in the doc shows 23 filler characters at the end, same with OCR captured texts, but the result shows 21 filler characters in the first line.

In the second line, the last 16 characters are 15 filler characters and the number "2", same in OCR, but the results show 13 filler characters and not the rest.

Is there a way to better synthesize these OCR extracted values?
@Hamish good point. We can check if the template was updated to the latest

Hi @Hamish
Can you try experimenting with Table/checkbox option enabled (not yet suggesting we use that - since in current an prior release there are some other side effects here which are addressed in 24.36). This will use FR engine and it may work slightly better.
@Ananya - Can you share the latest template for Passport?
